message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Emphatic Interpretations of Object Marking in Bantu Languages
Paper Abstract: This paper investigates emphatic interpretations of object marking in various Bantu languages. We focus on Lubukusu (spoken in Kenya) and Cinyungwe (spoken in Mozambique) in particular, but we also report initial evidence from other Bantu languages (mainly Tiriki, Wanga, and Ikalanga). In these languages, OM-doubling—the co-occurrence of an object marker with a lexical DP object—is infelicitous in neutral pragmatic contexts. However, we show that certain contexts make OM-doubling possible. In these contexts, OM-doubling constructions receive particular emphatic interpretations that are very different from interpretations of non-doubling object marking constructions. We identify at least four types of these interpretations: verum, mirativity, exhaustivity, and intensity. We show that emphatic interpretations of OM-doubling are widespread among Bantu languages, and we provide strategies for identifying and analyzing them. While this paper is primarily descriptive, we discuss a possible analysis of these interpretations as conventional implicatures, influenced by recent work on a similar range of emphatic interpretations arising from focus fronting in Indo-European languages.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Tiriki language:

Tiriki, or known by the autoglossonym Lutirichi, is a language variety spoken in western Kenya and eastern Uganda within the Luyia language family.(no content)It is the southeasternmost of the Luyia dialects, spoken primarily in Hamisi Constituency in Vihiga County, Western Province, Kenya.

The Tiriki language is spoken by the Tiriki people, an ethnic group in the region. The Tiriki speak Ludiriji (more widely referred to Lutirichi or Tiriki, according to Ethnologue) and are located in various localities north of Hamisi District in Kenya's Western Province.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Lubukusu language:

Lubukusu is listed among the related but distinct languages that linguists usually treat as part of the Luhya language cluster. The Luhya speak a cluster of mutually intelligible Bantu languages often referred to collectively as "Luhya" or OluLuyia.

Bukusu (a related term) is a dialect of the Masaba language spoken by the Bukusu tribe of the Luhya people of western Kenya. The Gisu dialect in eastern Uganda is mutually intelligible with Bukusu, spoken by ethnic Luhya in western Kenya.

The Bukusu tribe lives in Bungoma district, which borders Uganda to the west and Kakamega district of Kenya to the east. As of the 2019 Kenya census, 6,823,482 Kenyans – about 14 percent of the national population – identified as Luhya, making them the second largest ethnic group in the country after the Kikuyu.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Object marking linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Differential object marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_object_marking"},{"title":"Differential argument marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_argument_marking"},{"title":"Object (grammar) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Marker (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marker_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Markedness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markedness"},{"title":"Topic marker - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic_marker"},{"title":"Nominative–accusative alignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nominative–accusative_alignment"},{"title":"Object–subject–verb word order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object-subject-verb"},{"title":"Subject–object–verb word order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subject–object–verb_word_order"},{"title":"Marking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marking"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about object marking in linguistics:

## Overview

In linguistics, differential object marking (DOM) is the phenomenon in which certain objects of verbs are marked to reflect various syntactic and semantic factors.(no content)One form of the more general phenomenon of differential argument marking, DOM is present in more than 300 languages.

## Key Features

Typically, direct objects that are more prominent are more likely to be overtly case-marked. The notion of prominence is based on several properties:

A common basis for differentially marking direct objects is the notion of "prominence," which reflects two properties that can be understood along decreasing scales: definiteness (or specificity) and animacy.(no content)Some languages mark for only one of these properties (e.g., animacy), while others' markings reflect combinations of them.

## Examples

Other examples of languages with differential object marking are Persian, Turkish, Copala Triqui, Khasi, Tamil, Malayalam, Hindi, Marathi, Kham, Hebrew and Amharic.(no content)In languages like Turkish, Kazakh and Sakha, more "prominent" objects take an overt accusative marker while nonspecific ones do not.

## Semantic Factors

Beyond animacy and definiteness, another property that triggers differential object marking in some languages is the way the action of a verb affects the direct object.

Web search results for query: "Ikalanga language"

Links: [{"title":"Kalanga language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalanga_language"},{"title":"Kalanga people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalanga_people"},{"title":"Masunga - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Masunga_Senior_Secondary_School"},{"title":"Karanga - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Karanga"},{"title":"Kalanguya language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_639:ify"},{"title":"Kalanguya people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kalanguya_people"},{"title":"Yaka language (Congo–Angola) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_639:lnz"},{"title":"Igala language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Igala_language"},{"title":"Ikarranggal language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ikarranggali_language"},{"title":"Holoholo people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holoholo_people"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about the Ikalanga language:

Ikalanga (also called TjiKalanga in Zimbabwe) is a Bantu language spoken by the Kalanga people in Botswana and Zimbabwe which belongs to the Shonic (Shona-Nyai) branch of the Bantu languages, within the Niger-Congo languages.(no content)The iKalanga language is closely related to the Nambya, TshiVenda, and KheLobedu languages of Zimbabwe and South Africa.(no content)Linguists place Kalanga and Nambya (in the Hwange region of Zimbabwe) as the western branch of the Shona group (or Shonic, or Shona-Nyai) group of languages.

**Dialects:** The language has a number of tribal dialects depending on which part of the tribal territory you are situated, including the Talaunda dialect, the Lilima dialect, Jawunda dialect, the Nanzwa dialect, Tjigwizi dialect as well as Tjindodondo dialect (dominant in Zimbabwe).

**Status and Usage:** Kalanga is recognized as an official language by the Zimbabwean Constitution of 2013 and is taught in schools in areas where its speakers predominate.(no content)The BaKalanga of Botswana are the second largest ethnic group in the country, and their Kalanga language being the second most spoken in the country (most prevalent in the North).(no content)The TjiKalanga language of Zimbabwe is the third most spoken language in the country, however, being recognized as a Western Shona branch of the Shona group of languages.

Web search results for query: "Focus fronting linguistics"

Links: [{"title":"Focus (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Focus_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Information structure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_structure"},{"title":"Fronting (sound change) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fronting_(sound_change)"},{"title":"Topic and comment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Topic_and_comment"},{"title":"Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistics"},{"title":"Usage-based models of language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usage-based_linguistics"},{"title":"Th-fronting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th-fronting"},{"title":"Prosody (linguistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Prosody_(linguistics)"},{"title":"Fronting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fronting"},{"title":"Forensic linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forensic_linguistics"}]

Based on the search results, I found information about focus in linguistics, though the results don't contain a specific detailed article dedicated exclusively to "focus fronting" as a single unified concept. However, I can provide relevant information about focus and fronting as they relate to linguistics:

## Focus in Linguistics

In linguistics, focus is a grammatical category that conveys the part of the sentence that contributes new, non-derivable, or contrastive information.(no content)Focus may be highlighted either prosodically or syntactically or both, depending on the language.

## Fronting as a Syntactic Mechanism

In the context of syntax, focus can be done by assigning focus markers, or by preposing (moving an element to the front of a clause). Web search results for query: "Conventional implicature pragmatics"

Links: [{"title":"Implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implicature"},{"title":"Paul Grice - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Grice"},{"title":"Scalar implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scalar_implicature"},{"title":"Pragmatics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pragmatics"},{"title":"Cooperative principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_principle"},{"title":"Presupposition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Presuppose"},{"title":"Talk:Implicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Implicature"},{"title":"Explicature - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Explicature"},{"title":"Implication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Implies"},{"title":"Craige Roberts - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craige_Roberts"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about conventional implicature in pragmatics:

## Definition

In pragmatics, a subdiscipline of linguistics, an implicature is something the speaker suggests or implies with an utterance, even though it is not literally expressed. Conventional implicature is a specific type of implicature introduced by Paul Grice.

## Key Characteristics

The difference between conventional implicature and conversational implicature lies in the fact that what a speaker conventionally implicates by uttering a sentence is tied in some way to the timeless meaning of part of the sentence, whereas what a speaker conversationally implicates is not directly connected with timeless meaning.(no content)A conversational implicature is said to be non-detachable when, after the replacement of what is said with another expression with the same literal meaning, the same conversational implicature remains. This distinguishes them from conventional implicatures. This means conventional implicatures can be "detached" from their specific linguistic forms—if you replace the words, the implicature may disappear.

## Famous Example

Grice's best-known example of conventional implicature involves the word 'but', which, he argues, differs in meaning from the word 'and' only in that we typically conventionally implicate something over and above what we say with the former but not with the latter. In uttering the sentence 'She was poor but she was honest', for example, we say merely that she was poor and she was honest, but we implicate that poverty contrasts with honesty.(no content)Grice did not elaborate much on the notion of conventional implicature, but many other authors have tried to give more extensive theories of it, including Lauri Karttunen and Stanley Peters, Kent Bach, Stephen Neale, and Christopher Potts.

Links: [{"title":"Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bantu_languages"},{"title":"List of Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Bantu_languages"},{"title":"Southern Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Southern_Bantu_languages"},{"title":"Great Lakes Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Lakes_Bantu_languages"},{"title":"Konjo language (Bantu) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Konjo_language_(Bantu)"},{"title":"Bantu peoples - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bantu_peoples"},{"title":"Atong language (Cameroon) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Atong_language_(Grassfields_Bantu)"},{"title":"Northeast Coast Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northeast_Coast_Bantu_languages"},{"title":"Category:Great Lakes Bantu languages - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Great_Lakes_Bantu_languages"},{"title":"Bantu expansion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bantu_expansion"}]

Here's an overview of Bantu languages based on the search results:

## Overview

Bantu languages are largely spoken southeast of Cameroon, and throughout Central, Southern, Eastern, and Southeast Africa.(no content)The total number of Bantu speakers is estimated to be around 350 million in 2015 (roughly 30% of the population of Africa or 5% of the world population).

## Number of Languages

Depending on the definition of "language" or "dialect", it is estimated that there are between 440 and 680 distinct languages.

## Major Languages

Major Bantu languages include Lingala with more than 20 million speakers (Congo, DRC), followed by Zulu with 13.56 million speakers (South Africa), Xhosa, with 8.2 million speakers (South Africa and Zimbabwe), and Shona with less than 10 million speakers (if Manyika and Ndau are included), while Sotho-Tswana languages (Sotho, Tswana and Pedi) have more than 15 million speakers (across Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Zambia).

## Etymology and History

The technical term Bantu, meaning "human beings" or simply "people", was first used by Wilhelm Bleek. A common characteristic of Bantu languages is that they use words such as muntu or mutu for "human being" or in simplistic terms "person", and the plural prefix for human nouns starting with mu- (class 1) in most languages is ba- (class 2), thus giving bantu for "people".

## Origin and Migration

The Bantu languages descend from a common Proto-Bantu language, which is believed to have been spoken in what is now Cameroon in Central Africa. An estimated 2,500–3,000 years ago (1000 BC to 500 BC), speakers of the Proto-Bantu language began a series of migrations eastward and southward, carrying agriculture with them.

Major Bantu languages include Lingala with more than 20 million speakers (Congo, DRC), followed by Zulu with 13.56 million speakers (South Africa), Xhosa, with 8.2 million speakers (South Africa and Zimbabwe), and Shona with less than 10 million speakers (if Manyika and Ndau are included), while Sotho-Tswana languages (Sotho, Tswana and Pedi) have more than 15 million speakers (across Botswana, Lesotho, South Africa, and Zambia).

## Etymology and History

The technical term Bantu, meaning "human beings" or simply "people", was first used by Wilhelm Bleek. A common characteristic of Bantu languages is that they use words such as muntu or mutu for "human being" or in simplistic terms "person", and the plural prefix for human nouns starting with mu- (class 1) in most languages is ba- (class 2), thus giving bantu for "people".

## Origin and Migration

The Bantu languages descend from a common Proto-Bantu language, which is believed to have been spoken in what is now Cameroon in Central Africa. An estimated 2,500–3,000 years ago (1000 BC to 500 BC), speakers of the Proto-Bantu language began a series of migrations eastward and southward, carrying agriculture with them.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about exhaustivity semantics in linguistics:

## Definition

In linguistics, exhaustivity is the phenomenon where a proposition can be strengthened with the negation of certain alternatives. 

## Example

In response to the question "Which students got an A?", the utterance "Ava got an A" has an exhaustive interpretation when it conveys that no other students got an A.(no content)It has a non-exhaustive interpretation when it merely conveys that Ava was among the students who got an A.

## Research Focus

Exhaustivity is a major topic in the linguistic subfields of semantics and pragmatics.(no content)Research on the topic aims to explain when and why expressions receive exhaustive interpretations, with particular factors including focus, disjunction, questions, and polarity items.

## Theoretical Debate

A major theoretical issue is whether exhaustivity is a semantic entailment encoded in the grammar, a pragmatic implicature arising from Gricean social cognition, or some combination of the two.

Links: [{"title":"Mirativity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirativity"},{"title":"Evidentiality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evidentiality"},{"title":"Mimetic theory of speech origins - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mimetic_theory_of_speech_origins"},{"title":"Metalinguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metalinguistics"},{"title":"Mirror theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mirror_theory"},{"title":"Microlinguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microlinguistics"},{"title":"Meroitic language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meroitic_language"},{"title":"Linguistic relativity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_relativity"},{"title":"Linguistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistics"},{"title":"Linguistic typology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linguistic_typology"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of mirativity in linguistics:

## Definition

Mirativity, initially proposed by Scott DeLancey, is a grammatical category in a language, independent of evidentiality, that encodes the speaker's surprise or the unpreparedness of their mind.(no content)Grammatical elements that encode the semantic category of mirativity are called miratives (abbreviated MIR).

## Examples and Functions

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! I've successfully completed the analysis of this paper. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification:** This paper has been classified as a **contribution** paper because it proposes new analyses and frameworks for understanding emphatic interpretations in Bantu languages.

**Key Triples Identified (11 total):**

The analysis identified 11 key entities relevant to this paper:

**Language/Languages Used:**
- Bantu languages (family of languages studied)
- Bukusu dialect (Lubukusu - primary research subject)
- Nyungwe language (Cinyungwe - primary research subject)
- Idaxo-Isuxa-Tiriki language (Tiriki - supporting evidence)
- Luhya people (Wanga language dialect)
- Kalanga language (Ikalanga - supporting evidence)

**Linguistic Concepts Used:**
- Differential object marking (core phenomenon: OM-doubling)
- Implicature (proposed theoretical framework)
- Focus (linguistics) (comparison to Indo-European languages)

**Linguistic Concepts Proposed (Novel Contributions):**
- Mirativity (identified as emphatic interpretation type)
- Exhaustivity (identified as emphatic interpretation type)

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and validated. The validation script confirms the JSON file meets all requirements with proper relations (9 "uses" and 2 "proposes") and all entity types classified as linguistic concepts.
